thread.title: First pictures of heavily pregnant mum and two toddlers killed in devastating fire at women's refuge
thread.title_full: First pictures of heavily pregnant mum and two toddlers killed in devastating fire at women's refuge

author: Sophie Evans
title: First pictures of heavily pregnant mum and two toddlers killed in devastating fire at women's refuge
text:
News First pictures of heavily pregnant mum and two toddlers killed in devastating fire at women's refuge Mum-to-be Ann-Marie O'Brien, her two-year-old daughter Paris and a three-year-old called Holly all perished in the blaze on International Women's Day Share By Sophie Evans LAURA LYNE EMMA MCMENAMY STEPHEN MCDERMOTT BARRY ARNOLD 15:15, 8 MAR 2017 Ann-Marie O'Brien was seven months pregnant (Photo: Dublin Live) Share Get daily   Thank you for subscribing!   
These are the first pictures of the heavily pregnant mum and two toddlers who died after a fire at a women's refuge in the early hours of today. 
Ann-Marie O'Brien, 27, who was seven months pregnant, and her two-year-old daughter, Paris, perished in the horror blaze in west Dublin, Ireland. 
Another toddler, a three-year-old called Holly, also died after the fire, which broke out at an apartment complex at around 2.30am. 
A second woman and a four-year-old boy, who are yet to be named, are fighting for their lives in hospital following the tragedy, Dublin Live reports. 
It is understood the pair went to the apartment in the Clondalkin area with Holly for a sleepover to visit Ann-Marie and Paris. Ann-Marie's two-year-old daughter, Paris, pictured, was killed in the blaze (Photo: Dublin Live) Another toddler, a three-year-old called Holly, also died after the fire (Photo: Dublin Live) Garda at the scene of the apartment fire in Dublin, Ireland (Photo: PA) 
It's not yet known what started the fire but it's believed it was an electrical fault 
Fire rescue teams were on the scene within a few minutes and took two women and three children from a first-floor apartment. 
Tragically, one of the women and two of the kids were pronounced dead at hospital following the blaze, gardai said. 
The trio have since been identified as mum-to-be Ann-Marie, her toddler daughter Paris and little Holly. 
The second woman, aged in her 30s, and the little boy were said to be in a critical condition in Our Lady's Hospital in Crumlin. 
The apartment complex is used by the domestic violence charity Sonas to provide short term accommodation for women and children. Local Lisa Kinsilla Coleman (centre) delivers flowers to the scene of the blaze (Photo: PA) The fatal blaze broke out in the Clondalkin area at about 2.30am today (Photo: PA) Read More 
Three other apartments in the building were not affected by the fire. 
All of the victims were from the south Dublin area. 
Today, tributes were being paid to Ann-Marie, Paris and Holly. 
One family friend said: "I am so sad for the family. Please oh God in heaven keep this family in your prayers. Never heard anything like it. 
"Can't imagine how they feel." 
Another added: "Never heard worse. Everyone pray for their families at this very sad time", while another said: "RIP to the three who lost their lives and praying the other two get better. Heartbreaking.". 
A spokesman for Dublin Fire Brigade said a number of 999 calls were made about the blaze, with the first alert coming in at 2.33am. The apartment complex is used to provide short term accommodation for women and children (Photo: PA) A spokesman for Dublin Fire Brigade said a number of 999 calls were made about the blaze (Photo: PA) Read More Huge fire sees plume of smoke tower over Glasgow as shipyard blaze triggers series of explosions 
It is understood the first crews were on the scene within five minutes. 
"We got numerous calls in about it which would indicate that the fire was noticeable," a spokesman said. 
"The fire alarm in the apartment had also gone off." 
The fire appears to have broken out in a first floor unit where a vent and one of the windows appeared blackened this morning. 
Paramedics treated the five victims of the blaze in the grounds of the Cluainin Cronan complex, next to the Grand Canal. 
They used resuscitation techniques, before the two women and three young children were transferred to hospitals by ambulance. 
Seven residents of apartments in the same complex were evacuated during the emergency. Gardai appealed for witnesses to come forward following the fire (Photo: PA) 
Children's Minister Katherine Zappone said her thoughts and prayers were with all those affected by the Clondalkin fire. 
Gardai, meanwhile, appealed for witnesses to come forward. 
The apartment complex - used by Sonas to house women and kids who have sought refuge from domestic violence - has been sealed off. 
A technical examination to try to determine the cause of the devastating fire is expected to take place later today. 
In a separate incident, a number of people were injured after a blaze broke out in an apartment complex in Dominick Street in Dublin's north inner city. 
Twenty people were either rescued or managed to flee the building and some of those who escaped the fire were treated for the effects of smoke inhalation. 
Eoin O Broin, Sinn Fein TD in Dublin Mid-West and an elected representative in the Clondalkin area for many years, said locals were numb with shock. Tributes left at the scene of the tragedy, which has left residents shocked (Photo: PA) 
He described the Clondalkin fire as "numbingly heartbreaking". 
He told Dublin Live: “While any loss of life is always incredibly sad, to hear of the death of two young children and a third critically ill in hospital is really just numbingly heartbreaking. 
“We know the building is a step-down facility that provides a six-month accommodation while women and children are being housed permanently. 
“A lot of the women would be local women who would be well-known in the community, and even those that would be here for short periods would be well integrated into the community; their children would be in local schools. 
“It’s a very well-run facility and a really important facility in Clondalkin, but in some sense the nature of the accommodation makes no difference. 
“There are families who have lost loved ones today, and both of those families and the wider community are grieving for them. A technical examination to try to determine the cause of the blaze is expected to take place later today (Photo: PA) 
“I’ve spoken to a number of residents here this morning, and they’re absolutely shocked and numb with the news that they’re hearing." 
Two women who live in the area described the incident as "absolutely shocking". 
“The women in there are already going through enough as it is and then to have that and then the other people to witness it as well," they said. 
“You’d wonder how things like this could happen in this day and age, babies, it’s shocking, just horrific. 
"Our prayers are with the other woman and child now, they’re still in hospital. 
“All you can do now is pray for them.” 
The woman and four-year-old boy who remain in hospital were said to have suffered the effects of smoke inhalation. 
Inspector Ken McLaughlin, based at Clondalkin Garda station, said examinations were continuing to establish the cause of the fire. 
"I'd like to express our sincere sympathies for the families of those that are involved in this incident. It's a terrible tragedy," he said. Eoin O Broin, Sinn Fein TD in Dublin Mid-West, said: "It is terrible, heartbreaking news" (Photo: PA) 
Fiona Ryan, CEO of Sonas, paid tribute to the victims of the fire. 
"We are absolutely devastated," she said. 
"Our sympathies and condolences are with the relatives and friends of the deceased and all those impacted by this awful tragedy." 
Ms Ryan added that the charity was liaising with gardai and fire chiefs investigating the circumstances of the fire. 
"We are currently supporting other families in the apartment complex including those unable to return to their homes because of fire damage, for whom we are sourcing alternative accommodation," she said. 
She continued: "We would ask that the privacy of all families residing in this complex be respected at this time of loss." 
Today, March 8, is International Women's Day. The day marks the appreciation and achievement of women across the world. 
It also commemorates the struggle for women's rights. Like us on Facebook
